channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Texas and California Race Forward With Rival Redistricting Efforts
item.description: Lawmakers in the nation’s two most populous states were planning to vote Thursday on competing proposals as the battle over U.S. House maps intensifie...

item.title: Women in Indian Sports Sweat for Their Share of a Booming Market
item.description: Female athletes are using social media to increase viewership and seek better sponsorship deals in a field long dominated by men.

item.title: Beyond snubbing Tinder, Bumble, and casual flings, more than half of Gen Z is spending $0 monthly on dating, BofA finds
item.description: Gen Z’s economic anxiety—as well as disinterest in casual dating—has led many young people to spend little to nothing on dates.

item.title: Starbucks’ CEO is ditching a merit system and giving all salaried staff a flat 2% pay raise instead
item.description: The coffee chain cited limiting costs during a turnaround effort as it’s reason for the modest pay bump.

item.title: Zelensky, Back From Washington, Projects More Confidence in Peace Talks
item.description: The Ukrainian leader returned with a U.S. commitment to participate in security guarantees for Kyiv in a postwar settlement.

item.title: How Target let Walmart steal its rizz
item.description: Also: All the news and watercooler chat from Fortune.

item.title: One Sentence in the Constitution Is Causing America Huge Problems
item.description: An amendment that can help save our democracy.

item.title: Southeast Asia’s ‘incredibly dynamic’ Islamic finance market is drawing in non-Islamic players
item.description: Mambu, an Amsterdam based, SaaS firm is banking on the region's younger people gravitating towards financial solutions that adhere to Islamic principl...

item.title: Israel’s Looming Plans for Gaza City, and a Surge in Stalking in Women’s Sports
item.description: Plus, why steamy fan fiction is topping the best-seller list.

item.title: This Gen Zer washed his college basketball team’s dirty clothes to prove his passion—now he’s one of the youngest interns ever at the NBA
item.description: Mocked as ‘mop boy,’ Daniel Sung turned a year of college basketball grunt work into a dream NBA internship, LinkedIn fame, and multiple startup offer...

item.title: How Tiffany Trump’s Husband Benefited From Proximity to Power
item.description: A Times investigation found that Michael Boulos and his family benefited financially from proximity to his in-laws for years.

item.title: Women in Indian Sports Sweat for Their Share of a Booming Market
item.description: Female athletes are using social media to increase viewership and seek better sponsorship deals in a field long dominated by men.

item.title: Wisconsin Woman Who Flew to UK to Try to Kill a Man Gets 30-Year Sentence
item.description: Aimee Betro, 45, was convicted this month of attempting to shoot a man near Birmingham, England, in 2019.

item.title: Zelensky, Back From Washington, Projects More Confidence in Peace Talks
item.description: The Ukrainian leader returned with a U.S. commitment to participate in security guarantees for Kyiv in a postwar settlement.

item.title: Brazil-U. S. Talks on Mining Rare Earth Minerals Are Complicated by Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: Tensions between President Trump and Brazil’s leader could derail a promising alliance to unlock the world’s second largest reserve of the minerals.
